title: About
text:
(old website)

This site is devoted to the R programming, Python, Statistics and Data Science community at Harper Adams University. We meet Wednesdays at 4pm UK time on Teams and via our Slack workspace anytime.
Join us on Slack (kindly register with your real name, e.g. “Ronald Fisher”)
HARUG! is the Harper Adams R User Group:

Research methods in statistics and AI applications
Build data analysis skills and capacity
Group problem solving, live coding
Tutorials and resource sharing
Community


This group is supported by the research and teaching community at Harper Adams University and by students and alumnists of the MSc in Data Science for Global Agriculture, Food, and Environment, and is led by Ed Harris.

section: Quarto: an easier way for modern markdown…?
text:
Quarto: an easier way for modern markdown…?
Ed will expound upon the virtues of Quarto and do some live coding of setting up a new Quarto website using Github pages…
Quarto website
REALLY excellent documentation

section: Using R and python in Quarto
text:
Using R and python in Quarto

# Python in Quarto
print('hello world')

hello world



# R in Quarto
print("hello world")

[1] "hello world"

title: Schedule
text:
Schedule for The Future

2022-10-05 (meeting #100) (in person?) something fun to celebrate our 10^2 meeting (Ed)
2022-09-28 (meeting #101) What Natural Language Processing (NLP) is good for (Magda)

This group is supported by the research and teaching community at Harper Adams University and by students and alumnists of the MSc in Data Science for Global Agriculture, Food, and Environment, and is led by Ed Harris.

HARUG “Hello world” using Quarto
New HARUG! webpage using Quarto and Github Pages.
Quarto is a new(ish) markdown-style language that has a very simple workflow and can be use to make sophisticated webpages, slides, and reports.
While it is probably easier and more modern than plain markdown or R Markdown, a big advantage is that it can be used to make documents with live code for a variety of languages, including both R and Python.
Quarto website
REALLY excellent documentation
Good blog post about setting a quarto website up

section: You can render and use both R and python in Quarto
text:
You can render and use both R and python in Quarto

# Python in Quarto
print('hello world')

hello world



# R in Quarto
print("hello world")

[1] "hello world"
